title: What is the most scientific religion? - Quora

response.answer_text: "Scientific" means knowledge generating.  In this sense, the most scientific religion isn't a long lived, stable, psychological or metaphysical religion like Buddhism, Hinduism, or high church Christianity. They've made whatever contribution to science they were going to make a long time ago, and now mostly just curate it and teach it to further generations. That makes them historical, not scientific.. No, the most scientific religion would be some sort of short-lived cult which makes actual, testable predictions about miraculous and uncanny phenomena. It doesn't last long, but you learn a lot from it while it does. Its very existence is an experiment brough to its inevitable conclusion. There's a fundamental disconnection between scientificness and the things we value in religion. Science isn't one final state that's the same today, tomorrow, and yesterday. It's constantly in flux. The largest, most popular, and best known religions aren't; they are stable and convey an impression of certainty about things which we can't, properly speaking, ever be certain of. These qualities are opposites, but they're complementary. Long lived stable religions like Buddhism owe their longevity to the fact that they are not scientific: they are metaphysical, internal, subjective, psychological... These are qualities which complement science, but they are not scientific in themselves. Scientificness isn't necessarily something you'd want in a religion. A scientific religion is like a wrist watch with a built in toaster. It can tell you the time and toast bread, but it can't do either particularly well. A scientific religion isn't likely to do particularly good science, so we shouldn't expect it to.  Something can't be scientific without being testable. The more testable claims a religion makes, the more likely it is to be wrong about those claims. When you set out to make a scientific religion, you wind out with something like "scientific creationism," which is bad science and even worse theology.

its islam with no doubt.there are many and many proofs1. Origin of LifeWater is essential for all living things. We all know that water is vital to life but the Quran makes a very unusual claim:We made every living thing from water? Will they not believe? [21:30]In this verse water is pointed out as the origin of all life. All living things are made of cells. We now know that cells are mostly made up of water [4]. For example, 80% of the cytoplasm (basic cell material) of a standard animal cell is described as water in biology textbooks.The fact that living things consist mostly of water was discovered only after the invention of the microscope. In the deserts of Arabia, the last thing someone would have guessed is that all life came from water.2. IronIron is not natural to the earth. It did not form on the earth but came down to earth from outer space. This may sound strange but it’s true. Scientists have found that billions of years ago the earth was stuck by meteorites. These meteorites were carrying Iron from distant stars which had exploded [5].The Quran says the following on the origin of Iron:We sent down Iron with its great inherent strength and its many benefits for humankind [57:25]God uses the words ‘sent down’ for Iron. It is clear from the verse that Iron is not an earthly material, but was sent down for the benefit of humanity. The fact that Iron came down to earth from outer space, is something which could not be known by the primitive science of the 7th century.3. Sky’s ProtectionThe sky plays a crucial role in protecting the earth. The sky protects the earth from the lethal rays of the sun. If the sky did not exist then the sun’s radiation would have killed off all life on earth. It also acts like a blanket wrapped around the earth, to protect it from the freezing cold of space. The temperature just above the sky is approximately -270oC. If this temperature was to reach earth then the planet would freeze over instantly. The sky also protects life on earth by warming the surface through heat retention (greenhouse effect), and reducing temperature extremes between day and night [6]. These are some of the many protective functions of the sky.The Quran asks us to consider the sky in the following verse:We made the sky a protective ceiling. And yet they are turning away from Our signs! [21:32]The Quran points to the sky’s protection as a sign of God. The protective properties of the sky were discovered by scientific research conducted in the 20th century.4.MountainsThe Quran draws our attention to a very important characteristic of mountains:Did We not make the earth a resting place? And the mountains as stakes? [78:6-7]The Quran indicates that mountains have deep roots by using the word stakes to describe them. In fact mountains do have deep roots [7], and the word stakes is an accurate description for them. A book titled ‘Earth’ by Geophysicist Frank Press explains that mountains are like stakes, and are buried deep under the surface of the earth [8].Mount Everest (pictured below), the height of which is approximately 9 km above ground, has a root deeper than 125 km.The fact that mountains have deep ‘stake’ like roots was not known, until after the development of the theory of plate tectonics in the beginning of the 20th century [9].5. Expansion of the UniverseAt a time when the science of Astronomy was still primitive, the expansion of the universe was described in Quran:And it is We who have built the Universe with [Our creative] power and keep expanding it. [51:47]The fact that the universe is expanding was discovered in the last century. The physicist Stephen Hawking in his book ‘A Brief History of Time’ writes, “The discovery that the universe is expanding was one of the great intellectual revolutions of the 20th century.”[10].The Quran mentioned the expansion of the universe even before the invention of the telescope!6. Sun’s Orbit In 1512 the astronomer Nicholas Copernicus put forward his theory that the Sun is motionless at the centre of the solar system, and that the planets revolve around it. The belief that the Sun is stationary was widespread amongst astronomers until the 20th century. It is now a well-established scientific fact that the Sun is not stationary, but is moving in an orbit around the centre of our Milky Way galaxy [11].The Quran mentions the orbit of the Sun:It is He who created night and day, the Sun and the Moon, each floating in its orbit. [21:33]The Quran would have been wrong according to astronomers just a couple of decades ago. But we now know that the Quranic account of the Sun’s motion is consistent with modern Astronomy.7. The OceanThe Quran uses imagery to covey its deep meanings, here it describes the state of the unbelievers as:Darkness out in a deep ocean which is covered by waves, above which are waves, above which are clouds, layers of darkness, one upon the other. When one puts out his hand [therein], he can hardly see it. Those God gives no light to, they have no light. [24:40]It is commonly thought that waves only occur on the surface of the ocean. However oceanographers have discovered that there are internal waves that take place below the surface of the ocean. These waves are invisible to the human eye, and can only be detected by specialist equipment [12]. The Quran mentions darkness in a deep ocean above which are waves, above which are waves, then clouds above that. This description is not only remarkable because it describes the internal waves in the ocean, but also because it describes darkness deep in the ocean. A human being can dive no more than 70 metres without breathing equipment. Light is present at that depth, but if we go down 1000 metres it is completely dark [13]. 1400 years ago there were no submarines or specialist equipment to discover internal waves or the darkness deep inside the oceans.8. Lying and MovementThere was a cruel oppressive tribal leader named Abu Jahl who lived during the time of Prophet Muhammad (pbuh). God revealed a verse of the Quran to warn him:No Indeed! If he does not stop, We will seize him by the forehead, his lying, sinful forehead. [96:15-16]God does not call this person a liar, but calls his forehead (the front part of the brain) ‘lying’ and ‘sinful’, and warns him to stop.This verse is significant for two reasons. The first is that the front part of our brain is responsible for voluntary movement [14] .This is known as the frontal lobe. A book titled ‘Essentials of Anatomy and Physiology’ which includes the results of research on the functions of this area states: The motivation and the foresight to plan and initiate movements occur in the anterior portion of the frontal lobes, the prefrontal area [15]. The part of the brain that is responsible for movement is said to be seized if the man does not stop.Secondly, numerous studies have shown that this same region (frontal lobe) is responsible for the lying function of the brain [16].One such study at the University of Pennsylvania in which volunteers were asked questions during a computerized interrogation, it was found that when the volunteers were lying there was significantly increased activity in the prefrontal and premotor cortices (frontal lobe region) [17].The front part of the brain is responsible for movement and lying. The Quran links movement and lying to this area. These functions of the frontal lobe were discovered with medical imaging equipment which was developed in the 20th century.9. Pain Receptors For a long time it was thought that the sense of feeling and pain was dependent on the brain. However it has been discovered that there are pain receptors present in the skin [18]. Without these pain receptors, a person would not be able to feel pain.Consider the following verse on pain:We shall send those who reject Our revelations to the (Hell) Fire. When their skins have been burned away, We shall replace them with new ones so that they may continue to feel the pain: God is Almighty, All-Wise. [4:56]God tells the people who reject his message that when they are in Hell and their skins are burnt off (so they can’t feel any pain), he will give them new skins so that they continue to feel the pain.The Quran makes it clear that pain is dependent upon on the skin. The discovery of pain receptors in the skin is a fairly recent discovery for Biology.we conclude that:These are just some of the many scientific facts found in the Quran. It is important to note that the Quran is not a book of science, but that it is consistent with science. To claim that scientific facts in the Quran are due to coincidence would be irrational. The best explanation is that God revealed this knowledge to the Prophet Muhammad (pbuh).Just like the Quran contains knowledge about the natural world, it also contains information about the inner dimensions of our souls. It relates to our feelings, wants and needs. The Quran informs us that we have a purpose in life, and that following God’s guidance will lead us to inner peace in this life, and Paradise in the hereafter. And that rejection of his message will lead to depression in this life and Hellfire after death.

First of all, religion says almost nothing about science (literalists who say it does are doing it wrong), and science says almost nothing about religion (because science is tied to the observable, measurable universe and can thus never answers questions about anything beyond it). I think the only way to look at the question objectively would be to ask “Which religion has people doing the most science?”, and the answer to that has changed over the course of history. By “doing science” I mean taking measurements, drawing up hypotheses, testing them, finding the best one, and using that theory to explore further. The ancient Egyptians certainly did some, measuring the size of the Earth and building simple steam engines. The ancient Chinese did a lot of work, especially with chemicals and materials. The ancient Greeks thought a lot about it, but tended towards philosophy rather than true experimental research. The early years of Christianity were a bit of a scientific wasteland it’s true, and the west fell well behind the Islamic world in science. Islamic scholars made great progress in mathematics, astronomy, chemistry and medicine. However, once we reach the Age of Enlightenment, Christians clearly take the lead in scientific research. While the Enlightenment certainly included a large chunk of scepticism about religion, it also saw religious people having the freedom to move away from blind adherence to Scripture, allowing them explore the natural world around them, and they saw this as exploring God’s creation in an honourable way. Sponsoring scientific investigations became fashionable among the wealthy, and the results were widely shared and disbursed. Today, the field is more balanced again, with faithful people of all religions (and none) doing amazing scientific work. You should never take the noisy anti-science stance of a few American (or ISIS) nutjobs as representative of most people of faith. Throughout the centuries, religion has often (not always) been more a driver than a barrier to science.

Any religion where the results of what it teaches can be measured and applied in a practical way by anyone who follows a prescribed method fulfils scientific principle. Usually, 99% of the time, people are not willing to follow the prescribed method properly. They talk about it and claim it is not scientific without actually fulfilling the requirements to prove or disprove it. We need evidence. If a certain teaching prescribes a method or technique and claims that by following this method carefully you will receive evidence, unless you actually follow that method to conclusion you cannot pass judgement on it. That is like a scientist who disses a scientific experiment without actually undertaking research of the experiments explained in the paper. That usually happens when the scientist making the judgement has preconceived notions about the subject. Scientists are really good at that. They claim logic and intelligence about one thing but diss another because it doesn't fit into their system. Pasteur's research into bacteriology and germ theory rocked the boat, especially of theories of spontaneous generation of living organisms which was widely accepted then. Then you have Semmelweis who suggested doctors wash their hands before they operate. He was also dismissed as a fool as his observations conflicted with established scientific opinion of the time. His theories were widely accepted only years after his death.  The science of both Pasteur and Semmelweis are just examples of how the greatest scientist of the era would not accept anything outside of their field of vision, yet just a hundred and fifty or so years later, their science is regarded and plain common sense. So scientists themselves are the very best at denying scientific fact if it offends their own vision. This is often the case with scientists when it comes to applying scientific principle to religious/spiritual results. A sound religious teaching will prescribe a method, a technique by which, if carefully and accurately observed, guarantees results. The method will usually take more effort and discipline than many are willing to apply, so instead they simply dismiss it. That is very unscientific. As an example, the practice of something like the yogic technique of kriya yoga is very scientific. To do kriya the follower must follow a prescribed and very exacting method. Available to anything but requiring tremendous concentration and application over a long period of time. By applying this method, the student is told, you will experience certain events. If you do not experience these events, you should question your application to the prescribed technique.  So the method fulfils scientific requirements: it is predicted that by following the method precisely and for long enough one observes certain outcomes. These observations provide evidence as predicted which is the same for all who follow the method as prescribed. That is very scientific.  The method has been applied and proved perhaps countless times by thousands of people. Including some of the world's most highly decorated and recognised scientists. It could be said to be the highest religious and spiritual teaching and removes the notion of simple 'belief' as the basis of argument, even though belief is also good (no scientist worth his title undertook long periods of experiment without a belief in what he/she was seeking to achieve).  The method is also beyond being falsifiable, which is important to consider, because by following the technique accurately, the outcome is guaranteed. An alternative outcome is not possible, although many alternative outcomes have been claimed, always by people who have not undertaken the exact prescribed experiment or have not undertaken anything at all. Anyone can test it as it is no secret. However to receive the technique does require some preparation. Just as a child needs to graduate from high school before he can enter college, certain prerequisites need to be fulfilled before being taught the kriya technique. So to dismiss a particular religious teaching or method merely because one is not willing to undertake the prescribed method based on nothing more than a cynical and arrogant disrespect for religion is about as baseless as a religious person saying the world is only 4000 years because that's what my preacher told me.

The question is both ambiguous and makes assumptions that are not rational and scientific in itself. First, religion usually deals with the metaphysical and spiritual issues whereas science deals with the natural world. So followers of many religions would claim that their beliefs are outside of scientific inquiry. Second, what does “most” scientific mean? Do you mean a religion which is most compatible with modern scientific findings? To answer your question or more accurately rephrase it, you should be asking: Is there a religion that does not contain anything which is against scientifically proven facts? To this I would answer there is no such religion. All religions contain material that are incompatible with today’s understanding of the natural world. This is mainly due to the fact that religions were the ideas of people who lived before recent scientific discoveries and therefore had no idea about what we know now. It is usually their followers now that try to interpret their religious texts to match recent scientific findings. The same followers would reinterpret (and have done so in the past) the same text to match newer discoveries. As someone who believes in God but is secular and does not follow any religion I am very critical of attempts to frame any religion as being “scientific” and have criticized the main religions practiced today both from rational and scientific perspective in my book (available for free): The Kashfence Philosophy (Discovering through Rational and Scientific Analysis).

Buddhism is the most scientific. The Kalama Sutta states (Pali expression in parentheses): Do not go upon what has been acquired by repeated hearing (anussava),nor upon tradition (paramparā),nor upon rumor (itikirā),nor upon what is in a scripture (piṭaka-sampadāna)nor upon surmise (takka-hetu),nor upon an axiom (naya-hetu),nor upon specious reasoning (ākāra-parivitakka),nor upon a bias towards a notion that has been pondered over (diṭṭhi-nijjhān-akkh-antiyā),nor upon another's seeming ability (bhabba-rūpatāya),nor upon the consideration, The monk is our teacher (samaṇo no garū)Kalamas, when you yourselves know: "These things are good; these things are not blamable; these things are praised by the wise; undertaken and observed, these things lead to benefit and happiness," enter on and abide in them.'Thus, the Buddha named ten specific sources whose knowledge should not be immediately viewed as truthful without further investigation to avoid fallacies: Oral historyTraditionalNews sourcesScriptures or other official textsSuppositional reasoningPhilosophical dogmatismCommon senseOne's own opinionsExpertsAuthorities or one's own teacherInstead, the Buddha says, only when one personally knows that a certain teaching is skillful, blameless, praiseworthy, and conducive to happiness, and that it is praised by the wise, should one then accept it as true and practice it. Thus, as stated by Soma Thera, the Kalama Sutta is just that; the Buddha's charter of free inquiry: The instruction of the Kalamas (Kalama Sutta) is justly famous for its encouragement of free inquiry; the spirit of the sutta signifies a teaching that is exempt from fanaticism, bigotry, dogmatism, and intolerance. No religion is truly scientific. Religion is about subjective experience and faith divorced from and often contradicted by external evidence. Science is about mechanisms of reality that we can measure and test in a repeatable way no matter who does the experiment. When considering the origins of both Biblical and other religions, it is well to remember that many of the writers of these books never traveled more than a few days journey from the places they were born. And it is absolutely necessary to understand that many of the texts that have survived to modern times have been rewritten by authors more recent than the original. For example, there were three authors of the book of Isaiah, spread out across several hundred years. With the exception of the books of James (the brother of Jesus), the Christian new testament was written almost entirely by Paul and his disciples, beginning about 20 years after the Crucifixion. None of these authors ever heard Jesus of Nazareth speak. The essence of psychiatric neurosis is the ability to hold mutually contradictory concepts in mind at the same time and to demand that both should be accepted as true.

I can’t speak for all branches of Buddhism, but Buddhism is the one. Buddhism, which doesn’t depend on the belief in god, accepts all of science. There is a phrase, “the true aspect of all phenomena,” a line from the distant past, that pretty much sums it up. The point, and purpose, of Buddhism, is to learn how to relieve or eliminate suffering in our daily lives. It is unusually psychological (for a religion), and lays out the specific human behaviors that lead us into suffering. Denying reality - in this case, the findings of science - can only lead us into delusion, the source of so much personal pain and suffering. It is a religion, because it is socially organized and has a ritual - usually some form of chanting - that is designed to enable us to be in touch with our inner nature in our pursuit of peace and tranquility. Chanting is a way of finding out how function as human beings by searching our thoughts and feelings. However, Buddhism does not study science, but accepts the findings of the experts.

The relationship between religion and science is the subject of continued debate in philosophy and theology. To what extent are religion and science compatible? Are religious beliefs sometimes conducive to science, or do they inevitably pose obstacles to scientific inquiry? The interdisciplinary field of “science and religion”, also called “theology and science”, aims to answer these and other questions. It studies historical and contemporary interactions between these fields, and provides philosophical analyses of how they interrelate.
